column1: Vertebrae are the bones of the spine.
Osteoporosis is a disease in which bones become fragile.

- Trauma to the back - Tumors that started in the bone or spread to the bone from elsewhere - Tumors that start in the spine, such as multiple myeloma Having many fractures of the vertebrae can lead to kyphosis.
Often, they are discovered when x-rays of the spine are done for other reasons.

Over time, the following symptoms may occur: - Back pain that starts slowly, and gets worse with walking, but is not felt when resting - Loss of height, as much as 6 inches over time - Stooped-over posture, or kyphosis, also called a dowager's hump Pressure on the spinal cord from hunched over posture can, in rare cases, cause: - Numbness - Tingling - Weakness - Difficulty walking - Loss of control of the bowel or bladder
Your health care provider will perform a physical exam.
This may show: - A humpback, or kyphosis - Tenderness over the affected spinal bone or bones A spine x-ray shows at least 1 compressed vertebra that is shorter than the other vertebrae.

Other tests that may be done: - A bone density test to evaluate for osteoporosis - A CT or MRI scan, if there is a concern that the fracture was caused by a tumor or severe trauma (such as a fall or car accident)
Most compression fractures are seen in older people with osteoporosis.
The condition is usually treated with medicines and calcium supplements to prevent further fractures.

Pain may be treated with: - Pain medicine - Bed rest Other treatments may include: - Back braces, but these may further weaken the bones and increase the risk of more fractures - Physical therapy to improve movement and strength around the spine - A medicine called calcitonin to help relieve bone pain Surgery may be done if you have severe and disabling pain for more than 2 months that does not get better with other treatments.
After surgery you may need: - A brace for 6 to 10 weeks if the fracture was due to an injury - More surgery to join spine bones together or to relieve pressure on a nerve
Medicines to treat osteoporosis can help prevent future fractures.
